analytic.title: Binary bat algorithm

biblStruct.note: Received: 2 July 2013 / Accepted: 29 November 2013 Ó Springer-Verlag London 2013

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Bat algorithm (BA) is one of the recently proposed heuristic algorithms imitating the echolocation behavior of bats to perform global optimization. The superior performance of this algorithm has been proven among the other most well-known algorithms such as genetic algorithm (GA) and particle swarm optimization (PSO). However, the original version of this algorithm is suitable for continuous problems, so it cannot be applied to binary problems directly. In this paper, a binary version of this algorithm is proposed. A comparative study with binary PSO and GA over twenty-two benchmark functions is conducted to draw a conclusion. Furthermore, Wilcoxon's rank-sum nonparametric statistical test was carried out at 5 % significance level to judge whether the results of the proposed algorithm differ from those of the other algorithms in a statistically significant way. The results prove that the proposed binary bat algorithm (BBA) is able to significantly outperform others on majority of the benchmark functions. In addition, there is a real application of the proposed method in optical engineering called optical buffer design at the end of the paper. The results of the real application also evidence the superior performance of BBA in practice.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Over the last few decades, many heuristic optimization algorithms have been developed to solve complex computational problems. Some of them are particle swarm optimization (PSO) [1], genetic algorithm (GA) [2], simulated annealing (SA) [3], ant colony optimization (ACO) [4], gravitational search algorithm [5], charged system search [6], magnetic charged system search [7], ray optimization [8], and dolphin echolocation [9]. The flexibility and superior ability to deal with different problems make these algorithms popular among researchers compared to conventional optimization techniques. Moreover, it has been proven that there is no heuristic algorithm which can perform generally enough to solve all optimization problems [10]. In other words, the existing algorithms give satisfactory results in solving some problems but not all. Therefore, research is active in this area which results in the proposal of new heuristic algorithms every year.

Bat algorithm (BA) [11] is one of these novel heuristic optimization algorithms. Inspired by the echolocative behavior of bats, this algorithm carries the search process using artificial bats as search agents mimicking the natural pulse loudness and emission rate of real bats. The general steps of this algorithm are described in the next section. It has been proven that this algorithm is capable of providing competitive results compared to PSO and GA. The original version of BA has been proposed to solve problems with continuous real search spaces.

However, there are many optimization problems with discrete binary search spaces such as dimensionality reduction [12] and feature selection [13,14]. They need binary algorithms for their solution. Most of the wellknown meta-heuristic algorithms such as harmony search (HS) [15], differential evolution algorithm (DE) [16], magnetic optimization algorithm (MOA) [17], and gravitational search algorithm (GSA) [5] have binary versions which make them capable of optimizing binary problems. There are different methods to develop the binary version of a continuous heuristic algorithm while preserving the concepts of the search process. For instance, a set of harmony search considerations and pitch adjustment rules have been employed with the purpose of converting HS to binary HS (BHS) [18], while Wang et al. [19] proposed a probability estimation operator in order to solve discrete problems by DE. Furthermore, the Binary MOA [20] and Binary GSA [21] have been introduced utilizing transfer functions and position updating rules. Whereas BHS and BDE are different from their originating algorithms, the MOA and GSA retain the same concepts of position and velocity updating procedures. Consequently, the concepts used in converting MOA and GSA to binary algorithms are readily applicable to BA.

In this paper, a binary version of BA, named BBA, is proposed. The BBA will have artificial bats navigating and hunting in binary search spaces by changing their positions from ''0'' to ''1'' and vice versa. The rest of the paper is organized as follows:

Section 2 presents a brief introduction to BA. Section 3 discusses the basic principles of BBA. The experimental results of test functions and real application are demonstrated in Sects. 4 and 5, respectively. Finally, Sect. 6 concludes the work and suggests some directions for future study.

div.head: The bat algorithm
div.p: The BA has been inspired by the echolocation behavior of bats [11]. There are many types of bats in the nature. They are different in terms of size and weight, whereas all of them have quite similar behaviors when navigating and hunting. Bats use natural sonar in order to do this. The two main characteristics of bats when finding prey have been adopted in designing the BA. Bats tend to decrease the loudness and increase the rate of emitted ultrasonic sound when they chase prey. This behavior has been mathematically modeled as follows [11]:
In the BA, an artificial bat has a position vector, velocity vector, and frequency vector which are updated during the course of iterations as (1), (2), and (3):
div.formula: V i t þ 1 ð Þ¼V i t ð Þ þ ðX i t ð Þ À GbestÞF ið1Þ
X i t þ 1 ð Þ¼X i t ð Þ þ V i t þ 1 ð Þð2Þ
div.p: where Gbest is the best solution attained so far and F i indicates the frequency of i-th bat which is updated in each course of iteration as follows:
div.formula: F i ¼ F min þ ðF max À F min Þbð3Þ
div.p: where b is a random number of a uniform distribution in [0,1]. It is clear from the Eqs. ( 1) and ( 3) that different frequencies encourage artificial bats to have diverse propensity to the best solution. These equations could guarantee the exploitability of the BA. However, a random walk procedure is also has been used to perform the exploitation as follows:
div.formula: X new ¼ X old þ eA tð4Þ
div.p: In this formula, e is a random number in [-1,1], and A is the loudness of emitted sound that bats use to perform a exploration instead of exploitation as it is increased. The pseudocode and flow chart of this algorithm are presented in Figs. 1 and2, respectively. Note that rand is uniform random number between 0 and 1 in these figures.

According to these concepts, it can be stated that BA is a balanced combination of PSO and intensive local search. The balancing between these techniques is controlled by the loudness (A) and pulse emission rate (r). These two elements are updated as follows:
div.formula: A i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ aA i ðtÞ ð5Þ
r i t þ 1 ð Þ¼r i 0 ð Þ 1 À exp Àct ð Þ ½ ð6Þ
div.p: where a and c are constants; a is analogous to the cooling factor in SA [3]. Eventually, A i will equal zero, while the final value of r i is r(0). Note that both loudness and rate are updated when the new solutions are improved to guarantee that the bats are moving toward the best solutions.
div.formula: (rand < A i & f(x i ) < f(Gbest))
div.p: Accept the new solutions Increase r i and reduce A i end if Rank the bats and find the current Gbest end while Fig. 1 Pseudocode of bat algorithm [7] Neural Comput & Applic Yang justified the performance of the BA compared to PSO and GA [11]. He proved that the BA is able to outperform PSO and GA in terms of both improved local optima avoidance and convergence speed. However, this algorithm could not be employed to solve binary problems in its present form. In the next section, a binary version of this algorithm is developed and compared with binary PSO and GA.

div.head: Binary bat algorithm (BBA)
div.p: A binary search space can be considered as a hypercube. The search agents (particles) of a binary optimization algorithm can only shift to nearer and farther corners of this hypercube by flipping various numbers of bits [22]. Hence, in designing the binary version of BA, some basic concepts of the velocity and position updating process must be modified.

In the continuous version of BA, the artificial bats can move around the search space utilizing position and velocity vectors (or updated position vectors) within the continuous real domain. Consequently, the concept of position updating can be easily implemented for bats by adding velocities to positions using Eq. ( 2). However, the meaning of position updating is different in a discrete binary space [23]. In a binary space, due to dealing with only two numbers (''0'' and ''1''), the position updating process cannot be performed using Eq. ( 2). Therefore, a way must be found to use velocities for changing agents' positions from ''0'' to ''1'' or vice versa. In other words, a link has to be devised between velocity and position as well as revising the position updating in Eq. (2).

In discrete binary spaces, position updating means switching between ''0'' and ''1'' values. This switching should be done based on the velocities of agents. The question here is how the concept of velocity in a real space should be employed in order to update the positions in a binary space. According to [20][21][22], the idea is to change the position of an agent with the probability of its velocity. In order to do this, a transfer function is necessary to map velocity values to probability values for updating the positions. In other words, a transfer function defines the probability of changing a position vector's elements from 0 to 1 and vice versa. Needless to say, transfer functions force particles to move in a binary space. According to Rashedi et al. [21], the following concepts should be taken into account for selecting a transfer function in order to map velocity values to probability values.

• The range of a transfer function should be bounded in the interval [0,1], as they represent the probability that a particle should change its position. These concepts guarantee that a transfer function is able to map the process of search in a continuous search space to a binary search space while preserving similar concepts of the search for a particular evolutionary algorithm.
The transfer function that has been used for binary PSO is presented as Eq. ( 7) and Fig. 3 [22].
div.formula: S v k i t ð Þ À Á ¼ 1 1 þ e Àv k i t ð Þð7Þ
div.p: where v k i t ð Þ is the velocity of particle i in k-th dimension at iteration t.
After calculating the probabilities using transfer functions, a new position updating equation is necessary to update particles' position as follows [22]:
div.formula: x k i t þ 1 ð Þ¼ 0 If rand\S v k i t þ 1 ð Þ À Á 1 If rand ! S v k i t þ 1 ð Þ À Á &ð8Þ
div.p: where
div.formula: x k i t ð Þ and v k i t ð Þ
div.p: indicate the position and velocity of i-th particle at iteration t in k-th dimension.

This method has a drawback as the particles are forced to take values of 0 or 1 [24]. So the particles remain unchanged in their positions when their velocity values increase. However, according to the concepts mentioned above for designing a transfer function, a better way is to oblige the particles with high velocity to switch their positions. A v-shaped transfer function and position updating rule are proposed in order to do this as in Eqs. ( 9), (10), and Fig. 4.
div.formula: V v k i t ð Þ À Á ¼ 2 p arctan p 2 v k i ðtÞð9Þ
x k i t þ 1 ð Þ¼ x k i t ð Þ À Á À1 If rand\V v k i t þ 1 ð Þ À Á x k i t ð Þ rand ! V v k i t þ 1 ð Þ À Á &ð10Þ
div.p: where x k i t ð Þ and v k i t ð Þ indicate the position and velocity of i-th particle at iteration t in k-th dimension, and
div.formula: x k i t ð Þ À Á À1 is the complement of x k i t ð Þ.
div.p: The steps of utilizing the proposed transfer function to force particles to move in a binary search space are illustrated in Fig. 5.

In this paper, Eq. ( 9) is employed as the transfer function in order to map the velocities of BBA's bats to the probabilities of flipping their position vectors' elements. Consequently, the rules of ( 10) are used to update position vectors.
The general steps of BBA are presented in Fig. 6. The changes are underlined. In the following section, the efficiency of this algorithm is investigated.

div.head: Experimental results and discussion
div.p: In order to evaluate the performance of proposed binary BA called BBA, twenty-two standard benchmark functions are employed [25][26][27][28][29]. These benchmark functions can be divided into three different groups: unimodal, multimodal, and composite functions. Tables 1,2, 3 list the To represent each continuous variable in binary, 15 bits are used. It should be noticed that one bit is reserved for the sign of each functions' variable. Therefore, the dimensions of the bats are calculated as follows:
div.formula: Dim bat ¼ Dim function Â 15ð11Þ
div.p: where Dim bat indicates the dimension of each artificial bat in BBA and Dim function is the dimension of a particular benchmark function.
According to Eq. ( 11), the dimensions of particles are 75 (5 9 15) for unimodal and multimodal benchmark functions. The dimension is 150 (10 9 15) for composite benchmark functions.
The process of preparing continuous variables of the benchmark functions in binary for particles of BPSO is shown in Fig. 10.

BBA, BPSO, and GA have several parameters that should be initialized before running. Table 4 shows the initial values of basic parameters for these algorithms. Note that the BBA is implemented in Matlab and the source codes are available in http://www.alimirjalili.com or http://www. mathworks.com.au/matlabcentral/fileexchange/44707. The

div.head: i-th bat i-th bat Iteration=t Iteration=t+1
div.p: Transfer function
div.formula: Rand[0,1] Rand[0,1] Rand[0,1] . . . Rand[0,1] Rand[0,1] V(V 1 ) V(V 2 ) V(V 3 ) . . . V(V s ) BINARY SEARCH SPACE CONTINUOUS SEARCH SPACE X 1 X 2 X 3 . . . X s Position vector V 1 V 2 V 3 . . . V s Velocity vector X 1 X 2 X 3 . . . X s Position vector V 1 V 2 V 3 . . . V s Velocity vector V(x)
div.p: Equation ( 10)
Update (0 or 1)

Fig. 5 The process of mapping a continuous search space to a discrete search space 5,6, 7, 8, 9, 10. The results are averaged over 30 independent runs, and the best results are indicated in bold type. The average (Ave), standard deviation (SD), and median (Med) of the best-sofar solution in the last iteration are reported According to Derrac et al. [30], to improve the evaluation of evolutionary algorithms' performance, statistical tests should be conducted. In other words, it is not enough to compare algorithms based on the mean and standard deviation values [31]. A statistical test is necessary to prove that a proposed new algorithm presents a significant improvement over other existing methods for a particular problem.

In order to judge whether the results of the BBA differ from the best results of the other algorithms in a statistically significant way, a nonparametric statistical test, Wilcoxon's rank-sum test [32], was carried out at a 5 % significance level. The p values calculated in Wilcoxon's rank-sum test comparing BBA and other algorithms over all the benchmark functions are given in Tables 6, 8, and 10. In these tables, NA stands for ''not applicable'' which means that the corresponding algorithm could not statistically compare with itself in the rank-sum test. According to Derrac et al. [30], those p values that are \0.05 could be considered as strong evidence against the null hypothesis. In the following subsections, the details of the results and discussion at each group of benchmark functions are provided.

div.head: Unimodal benchmark functions
div.p: The unimodal benchmark functions have only one global solution, and there is no local solution for them. Consequently, they are useful to examine heuristic optimization
div.formula: f 1 x ð Þ ¼ P n i¼1 x 2 i 5 [ -100,100] 0 f 2 x ð Þ ¼ P n i¼1 x i j j þ Q n i¼1 x i j j 5 [ -10,10] 0 f 3 x ð Þ ¼ P n i¼1 P i jÀ1 x j 2 5 [ -100,100] 0 f 4 x ð Þ ¼ max i x i j j; 1 i n f g 5 [ -100,100] 0 f 5 x ð Þ ¼ P nÀ1 i¼1 100 x iþ1 À x 2 i À Á 2 þ x i À 1 ð Þ 2 h i 5 [ -30,30]0

f 6 x ð Þ ¼ P n i¼1 x i þ 0:5 ½ ð Þ 2 5 [ -100,100] 0 f 7 x ð Þ ¼ P n i¼1 ix 4 i þ random½0; 1Þ 5 [ -1.28,1.28] 0 Table 2 Multimodal benchmark functions Function Dim Range f min f 8 x ð Þ ¼ P n i¼1 Àx i sin ffiffiffiffiffiffi x i j j p À Á5
f 9 x ð Þ ¼ P n i¼1 x 2 i À 10cos 2px i ð Þþ10 Â Ã5
f 10 x ð Þ ¼ À20 exp À0:2 ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi 1 n P n i¼1 x 2 i q À exp 1 n P n i¼1 cos 2px i ð Þ À Á þ 20 þ e 5 [ -32,32]0
f 11 x ð Þ ¼ 1 4000 P n i¼1 x 2 i À Q n i¼1 cos xi ffi i p þ 1 5 [ -600,600]0

f 12 x ð Þ ¼ p n 10 sin py 1 ð Þþ P nÀ1 i¼1 y i À 1 ð Þ 2 1 þ 10 sin 2 py iþ1 ð Þ Â Ã þ y n À 1 ð Þ 2 n o þ P n i¼1 u x i ; 10; 100; 4 ð Þ y i ¼ 1 þ xiþ1 4 uðx i ; a; k; mÞ ¼ k x i À a ð Þ m x i [ a 0 Àa\x i \a k Àx i À a ð Þ m x i \ À a 8 < : 5 [ -50,50]0
f 13 x ð Þ ¼ 0:1 sin 2 3px 1 ð Þþ P n i¼1 x i À 1 ð Þ 2 1 þ sin 2 3px i þ 1 ð Þ Â Ã þ x n À 1 ð Þ 2 1 þ sin 2 2px n ð Þ Â Ã n o þ P n i¼1 u x i ; 5; 100; 4 ð Þ 5 [ -50,50]0
f 14 x ð Þ ¼ À P n i¼1 sin x i ð Þ Á sin iÁx 2 i p 2m ; m ¼ 10 5 [0,p] -4.687
f 15 x ð Þ ¼ e À P n i¼1 x i =b ð Þ 2m À 2e À P n i¼1 x 2 i ! Á Q n i¼1 cos 2 x i ; m ¼ 5 5 [ -20,20] -1
f 16 x ð Þ ¼ P n i¼1 sin 2 x i ð Þ Â Ã À exp À P n i¼1 x 2 i À Á È É Á exp À P n i¼1 sin 2 ffiffiffiffiffiffi x i j j p Â Ã 5 [ -10,10] -1 Neural Comput & Applic
div.p: algorithms in terms of convergence rate. Table 5 shows the results for these unimodal functions. As can be seen in this table, the BBA outperforms the other algorithms on all the unimodal benchmark functions in terms of the mean, standard deviation, and median of the results. According to the p values in Table 6, BBA do not only have a significant improvement in f 4 , but also this algorithm achieves significant improvement in all the remaining unimodal benchmark functions compared to other algorithms. Therefore, this is evidence that the proposed algorithm has high performance in finding the global solution of unimodal benchmark functions. Figure 11 illustrates the averaged convergence curves of all algorithms dealing with all unimodal benchmark functions over 30 independent runs. Note that all the convergence curves in the following subsections are also averaged As can be seen from these curves, the BBA has the fastest convergence rate. According to Tables 5,6, and Fig. 11, it can be concluded that the BBA tends to find the best solution in unimodal functions with a very fast convergence rate.

div.head: Multimodal benchmark functions
div.p: The results of the multimodal benchmark functions are provided in Table 7. It should be noticed that these benchmark functions have many local minima with the number increasing exponentially with dimension, so they are suitable to benchmark the ability of algorithms in avoiding local minima. As the results of mean, standard deviation, and median show, BBA performs better than the other algorithms in four of the multimodal benchmark functions. The BPSO and GA have the best results in three and two functions, respectively. The p values in Table 8 show that the results of algorithms in five out of nine benchmark functions are not significantly different. In the remaining functions (f 9 , f 11 , f 14 , and f 15 ), the results are not significantly dissimilar, and the BBA has the best results in f 9 and f 11 . So, it can be claimed that the results of BBA in these benchmark functions are slightly better than BPSO and GA. As can be observed in Fig. 12, the convergence rate of BBA in some cases is better than the other algorithms. According to Tables 7,8, and Fig. 12, it can be said that the BBA is capable of avoiding local minima with a good convergence rate for multimodal benchmark functions.

div.head: Composite benchmark functions
div.p: The results of composite benchmark functions are provided in Tables 9, 10, and Fig. 13. The results for BBA are apparently better than BPSO and GA for five composite functions. For the function f 18 , BPSO has the best results, closely followed by BBA. The p values of Wilcoxon's rank-sum in Table 10 show that the results of BPSO in f 18 are not significantly better than BBA or GA. The same is true for BBA in f 21 . Therefore, the results of BBA are significantly better in four out of six composite functions. The composite functions have very complex structures with many local minima which are highly similar to real-
Fig. 7 The 2-D versions of unimodal benchmark function
div.formula: Neural Comput & Applic (f 8 ) ( f 9 ) f 10 ) (f 11 ) (f 12 ) ( f 13 ) (f 14 ) ( f 15 ) ( f 16 )
div.p: Fig. 8 The 2-D versions of multimodal benchmark functions world problems, so the results can strongly show that the BBA has high in dealing with complex problems as well.

Figure 13 depicts the convergence curves of algorithms on composite benchmark functions. As it can be observed in this figure, the fastest convergence rate belongs to BBA, followed by BPSO. According to these results, it can be stated that BBA is capable of finding global solution with good convergence speed when dealing with composition benchmark functions.

Statistically speaking, Fig. 14 shows the final statistically significant results on all the benchmark functions whereby the BBA has the best results for twelve out of twenty-three benchmark functions, more than half. Moreover, Fig. 15 provides the final statistical results of convergence analysis over all the benchmark functions. This figure shows that BBA has the fastest convergence rate in sixteen out of twenty-two functions. The superiority of the results and high performance of BBA are due to several reasons:

• BA combines the major advantages of the previously proposed heuristic algorithms such as PSO and SA and their effects are seen in BBA as well • Loudness and pulse emission balance between exploration and exploitation assisting BBA to avoid local minima and then accelerate with fast convergence rate toward the global optimum over the course of iterations • The proposed v-shaped transfer function obliges bats to switch their positions when they are moving into unpromising area of the search space. However, the updating position rules for BPSO assign 0 or 1 to the particles.

According to this comprehensive comparative study and discussions, we state that this algorithm has merit among the other binary algorithms. The next section inspects the performance of the BBA in solving a real problem in optical engineering.

div.head: Real application
div.p: Over the last decade, there has been a growing interest in utilizing Photonic crystal (PC) due to its wide range of applications. The slow light in photonic crystal waveguide (PCW) is one of the attractive subjects for realizing slow light at room temperature [33]. PCW has been used in nonlinear optics [34], time-domain signal processing [35], and all-optical buffers [35,36]. The basic form of PCW is formed by engraving a row of hole in a triangle lattice PC silicon slab (Fig. 16). There are many theoretical and
div.formula: (Dim=5) X 1 X 2 X 3 X 4 X 5 X 1 X 2 X 3 X 4 X 5
div.p: Fig. 10 The procedure of preparing variables of benchmark functions in binary for BBA
div.formula: Neural Comput & Applic
div.p: experimental studies in the literature concentrating on slow in line defect PCWs [37][38][39][40][41]. In this subsection, we propose and optimize a new unit cell in PC lattice by using BBA to make a PCW with high buffering capabilities.
There are some preliminary concepts and definitions in slow light regime as follows:
In order to compare slow light devices with different lengths and operating frequencies, normalized delaybandwidth product (NDBP) is used as follows [41]:
div.formula: NDBP ¼ n g Á Dx=x 0ð12Þ
div.p: where n g is the average of group index, Dx is the normalized bandwidth, and x 0 is the normalized central frequency of light wave.

As may be inferred from Eq. ( 12), NDBP increases as Dx raises. However, the bandwidth and group index are in conflict. So, we need to increase both of them in order to maximize NDBP. Finding the optimum values for these two factors is considered as a challenging task as the literature shows.

In order to find these parameters, dispersion relations diagram is needed. So, it is usually calculated by a 2-D plane wave expansion (PWE) with slab equivalent index method [42]. The background refractive index is the effective refractive index of the guided transverse electric (TE) polarized mode in silicon-on-insulator (SOI) slab.
Note that a slab equivalent index is 3.18 for 400-nm-thick silicon slab in silicon dioxide which is used [43].

Figure 17 shows the calculated dispersion relation of PCW. The PC slab waveguide supports one even and one odd mode in the photonic band gap. The modes which lie below the light line of SiO 2 are intrinsically lossless in the vertical direction [41]. Apparently, both of these two modes are located below the light of SiO 2 . The even mode is chosen as the main propagation mode since its linear dispersion curve lays at large wave vectors. The group index n g is defined as follows [44]:
div.formula: n g ¼ C v g ¼ C dk dxð13Þ
div.p: where x is the dispersion, k indicates the wave vector, C is the velocity of light in free space, and n g shows group index. n g is changing in bandwidth range. So, we have to average it as follows [44]:
div.formula: n g ¼ Z x H x L n g ðxÞ dx Dxð14Þ
div.p: The presence of slow light usually coincides with huge group velocity dispersion (GVD) [45]. Generally speaking, low group velocity has high GVD which reduces the bandwidth of
div.formula: b 2 ¼ d 2 k dx 2 ¼ dn g dx 1 Cð15Þ
div.p: According to Zhai et al. [41], the first five rows of cells next to the defect have much effect on slow light. Consequently, the slow light and control dispersion can be achieved by designing the shape of these rows. The normalized bandwidth in PCW is a region of normalized frequency that the group index n g is considered as a constant with n g ± 10 % range [41]. Figure 18 shows the bandwidth region of n g . Kuramochi et al. [47] showed that the losses have n 2 g dependence, so large values of n g are not fruitful.

As each structural parameter varies during the optimization process, all bands vary in dispersion relation diagram. So, it is very important to consider the behavior of all bands to avoid band mixing [37,[48][49][50]. This will help to find the best parameters of the structure.

In this work, we divide the unit cell of the wave guide into 25 squares. Each square is known as an independent bit. Zero value for a bit means that the square should be empty (air), and one indicates that the square should not to be empty (filled by silicon). We want to find the binary unit cell with highest buffering capabilities (maximize buffering capability). Moreover, the parameters of the problem are in binary format. This is the reason of employing BBA to find the optimum shape for this problem. The wave guide and binary unit cell is shown in Fig. 19. As can be seen in this figure, there are 25 unit cells (parameters) to be optimized.
In the following subsections, the problem formulation and results are provided.

div.head: Problem formulation
div.p: The problem is mathematically formulated for BBA as follows:
div.formula: Consider : x ~¼ Bit24; . . .; Bit00 ½ ; Maximize : f x ð Þ ¼ NDBP ¼ n g Dx x 0 ; Subject to : max b 2 ðxÞ ð Þ\10 6 a=2pC 2 ; x H \min x up band À Á ; x L [ max x down band ð Þ ; where x H ¼ max x Guided mode ð Þ ; x L ¼ min x Guided mode ð Þ ; Dx ¼ x H À x L ; a ¼ x 0 Â 1; 550 ðnmÞð16Þ
div.p: Note that the second and third constraints of this problem are for avoiding band mixing. As the infeasibility handling method, we assign small negative objective function values (-100) to those candidate solutions that violate the constraints. The a parameter is lattice constant which is designed for bandwidth with 1,550 nm central wave length.

div.head: Calculation results and discussion
div.p: We solved this problem by BBA 10 times over 1,000 iterations and provide the best results in this sub-section. The best optimized binary unit cell obtained and the corresponding group index are shown in Figs. 20 and21, respectively. The slow light properties of the best binary unit cell obtained are presented in Table 11. The slow light parameters show that the optimized binary unit cell has a good optical buffer capability due to high bandwidth operation. The BBA proved its merit in optical buffer design in this study. It is worth mentioning that the optimized structure has a symmetric bandwidth around k 0 = 1,550 nm with no overlaps with other bands in the bandwidth region. This is the outcome of utilizing the BBA optimizer with considering constraints which allow us to confidently state that the obtained design is a feasible optimized design.
To sum up, it seems that the optimized structure is suitable for making optical buffer. Moreover, the obtained design is totally feasible with considering constraints.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this paper, a binary version of BA called BBA was proposed utilizing the concepts of transfer functions. In order to justify the performance, twenty-two benchmark functions were employed, and the results were compared with BPSO and GA. Furthermore, Wilcoxon's rank-sum nonparametric statistical test was carried out at 5 % significance level to judge whether the results of the BBA differ from the best results of the other algorithms in a statistically significant way. The results proved that the BBA has merit among binary heuristic optimization algorithms. The results of the BBA on the optical buffer design problem also proved that this algorithm can be effective for real problems as well.
For future studies, it is recommended to apply the BBA to different practical applications. The effects of different transfer functions on the performance of BBA are also worth investigating.
